file.content:
# Formalize Conjecture

To formalize conjecture NUM:

1. Read problem from `tidy/NUM.html`.
2. Formalize conjecture in lean and persist to `conjectures/NUM.lean`.
3. Build the file using the command `lake build conjectures/NUM.lean`.
4. Debug build until it runs successfully.

Documentation:

- Lean 4 docs: https://lean-lang.org/doc/reference/latest/
- Mathlib docs: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/

Things to consider:

- Note that build logs will throw warnings about sorry declarations. This is expected and fine for conjectures.

PROVED This has been solved in the affirmative.
Suppose $A=\{w_1,\ldots,w_n\}\subset S^2$ maximises\[\prod_{i<j}\lvert w_i-w_j\rvert\]over all possible sets of size $n$.

Is it true that\[\max_C\lvert \lvert A\cap C\rvert - \alpha_C n\rvert =o(n),\]where the maximum is taken over all spherical caps $C$ and $\alpha_C$ is the area of $C$ (normalised so that the entire sphere has area $1$)?
#991: [Er64b]
discrepancy
This is certainly solved, although it is unclear exactly who to attribute this to. Brauchart [Br08] says that this qualitative result follows from 'classical potential theory', and proves a quantitative decay rate of\[\max_C\lvert \lvert A\cap C\rvert - \alpha_C n\rvert \ll n^{3/4}.\]Marzo and Mas [MaMa21] cite an improvement of $\ll n^{2/3}$ due to Wolff in an unpublished manuscript, and themselves give a proof of $\ll n^{2/3}$ (as a special case of a more general result).

See also [988].

View the LaTeX source

This page was last edited 16 September 2025.

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     3→
     4→noncomputable section
     5→
     6→open Classical
     7→
     8→/-!
     9→# Erdős Problem #988
    10→
    11→If P ⊆ S² is a subset of the unit sphere then define the discrepancy
    12→  D(P) = max_C | |C ∩ P| - α_C |P| |,
    13→where the maximum is taken over all spherical caps C, and α_C is the
    14→appropriately normalised measure of C.
    15→
    16→Is it true that min_{|P|=n} D(P) → ∞ as n → ∞?
    17→
    18→This was proved (in any number of dimensions) by Schmidt [Sc69b].
    19→-/
    20→
    21→/--
    22→Erdős Problem #988 [Er64b]:
    23→
    24→For every M > 0, there exists N₀ such that for every finite set P of points
    25→on the unit sphere S² in ℝ³ with |P| ≥ N₀, there exists a spherical cap
    26→C(v,t) = {x ∈ S² : ⟪x, v⟫ ≥ t} (with v a unit vector and t ∈ [-1,1])
    27→such that the discrepancy ||C(v,t) ∩ P| - ((1-t)/2) · |P|| ≥ M.
    28→
    29→Here (1-t)/2 is the normalised surface area measure of the cap C(v,t) on S².
    30→-/
    31→theorem erdos_problem_988 :
    32→    ∀ M : ℝ, M > 0 →
    33→    ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
    34→      (∀ p ∈ P, ‖p‖ = 1) →
    35→      P.card ≥ N₀ →
    36→      ∃ (v : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3)) (t : ℝ),
    37→        ‖v‖ = 1 ∧ -1 ≤ t ∧ t ≤ 1 ∧
    38→        |((P.filter (fun x => @inner ℝ _ _ x v ≥ t)).card : ℝ) -
    39→          (1 - t) / 2 * (P.card : ℝ)| ≥ M :=
    40→  sorry
    41→
    42→end
    43→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic

noncomputable section

open Classical

/-!
# Erdős Problem #988

If P ⊆ S² is a subset of the unit sphere then define the discrepancy
  D(P) = max_C | |C ∩ P| - α_C |P| |,
where the maximum is taken over all spherical caps C, and α_C is the
appropriately normalised measure of C.

Is it true that min_{|P|=n} D(P) → ∞ as n → ∞?

This was proved (in any number of dimensions) by Schmidt [Sc69b].
-/

/--
Erdős Problem #988 [Er64b]:

For every M > 0, there exists N₀ such that for every finite set P of points
on the unit sphere S² in ℝ³ with |P| ≥ N₀, there exists a spherical cap
C(v,t) = {x ∈ S² : ⟪x, v⟫ ≥ t} (with v a unit vector and t ∈ [-1,1])
such that the discrepancy ||C(v,t) ∩ P| - ((1-t)/2) · |P|| ≥ M.

Here (1-t)/2 is the normalised surface area measure of the cap C(v,t) on S².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_988 :
    ∀ M : ℝ, M > 0 →
    ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
      (∀ p ∈ P, ‖p‖ = 1) →
      P.card ≥ N₀ →
      ∃ (v : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3)) (t : ℝ),
        ‖v‖ = 1 ∧ -1 ≤ t ∧ t ≤ 1 ∧
        |((P.filter (fun x => @inner ℝ _ _ x v ≥ t)).card : ℝ) -
          (1 - t) / 2 * (P.card : ℝ)| ≥ M :=
  sorry

end

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     3→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4→
     5→open Finset BigOperators
     6→
     7→/--
     8→A finset of natural numbers has distinct subset sums if every subset of it
     9→sums to a unique value.
    10→-/
    11→def HasDistinctSubsetSums (A : Finset ℕ) : Prop :=
    12→  ∀ s t, s ⊆ A → t ⊆ A → (∑ i ∈ s, i) = (∑ i ∈ t, i) → s = t
    13→
    14→/--
    15→Erdős's conjecture on sum-distinct sets (Problem #1):
    16→If A ⊆ {1, ..., N} is a sum-distinct set with |A| = n, then N ≫ 2^n.
    17→This is formalized as: there exists a constant c > 0 such that for any such set A,
    18→its maximum element N satisfies N ≥ c * 2^|A|.
    19→-/
    20→theorem erdos_problem_1_conjecture :
    21→  ∃ c : ℝ, c > 0 ∧ ∀ (A : Finset ℕ),
    22→    A.Nonempty →
    23→    (∀ x ∈ A, x > 0) →
    24→    HasDistinctSubsetSums A →
    25→    ∀ (N : ℕ), (∀ x ∈ A, x ≤ N) →
    26→    (N : ℝ) ≥ c * (2 : ℝ) ^ A.card :=
    27→sorry
    28→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic

open Finset BigOperators

/--
A finset of natural numbers has distinct subset sums if every subset of it
sums to a unique value.
-/
def HasDistinctSubsetSums (A : Finset ℕ) : Prop :=
  ∀ s t, s ⊆ A → t ⊆ A → (∑ i ∈ s, i) = (∑ i ∈ t, i) → s = t

/--
Erdős's conjecture on sum-distinct sets (Problem #1):
If A ⊆ {1, ..., N} is a sum-distinct set with |A| = n, then N ≫ 2^n.
This is formalized as: there exists a constant c > 0 such that for any such set A,
its maximum element N satisfies N ≥ c * 2^|A|.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_1_conjecture :
  ∃ c : ℝ, c > 0 ∧ ∀ (A : Finset ℕ),
    A.Nonempty →
    (∀ x ∈ A, x > 0) →
    HasDistinctSubsetSums A →
    ∀ (N : ℕ), (∀ x ∈ A, x ≤ N) →
    (N : ℝ) ≥ c * (2 : ℝ) ^ A.card :=
sorry

content.content:
1→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     2→import Mathlib.Data.Real.Sqrt
     3→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
     4→import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Complex.Arg
     5→import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Roots
     6→import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic
     7→
     8→open Polynomial Complex Real Finset BigOperators
     9→
    10→noncomputable section
    11→
    12→/-!
    13→# Erdős Problem #990
    14→
    15→Let f = a₀ + ⋯ + a_d xᵈ ∈ ℂ[x] be a polynomial. Is it true that, if f has
    16→roots z₁, …, z_d with corresponding arguments θ₁, …, θ_d ∈ [0, 2π), then
    17→for all intervals I ⊆ [0, 2π)
    18→
    19→  |#{θ_i ∈ I} − |I|/(2π) · d| ≪ (n · log M)^{1/2}
    20→
    21→where n is the number of non-zero coefficients of f and
    22→M = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / (|a₀| · |a_d|)^{1/2}.
    23→
    24→Erdős and Turán [ErTu50] proved such an upper bound with n replaced by d.
    25→-/
    26→
    27→/-- The argument of a complex number normalized to [0, 2π).
    28→    Returns 0 for z = 0. -/
    29→noncomputable def Complex.arg2pi (z : ℂ) : ℝ :=
    30→  if Complex.arg z < 0 then Complex.arg z + 2 * Real.pi else Complex.arg z
    31→
    32→/-- The number of roots (counted with multiplicity) of a polynomial whose
    33→    argument lies in the interval [α, β]. -/
    34→noncomputable def rootArgCount (f : Polynomial ℂ) (α β : ℝ) : ℕ :=
    35→  (f.roots.map Complex.arg2pi).countP (fun θ => decide (α ≤ θ ∧ θ ≤ β))
    36→
    37→/-- The Erdős–Turán measure M(f) = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / √(|a₀| · |a_d|). -/
    38→noncomputable def erdosTuranMeasure (f : Polynomial ℂ) : ℝ :=
    39→  (∑ i ∈ Finset.range (f.natDegree + 1), ‖f.coeff i‖) /
    40→    Real.sqrt (‖f.coeff 0‖ * ‖f.leadingCoeff‖)
    41→
    42→/--
    43→Erdős Problem #990 [Er64b]:
    44→
    45→Let f = a₀ + ⋯ + a_d xᵈ ∈ ℂ[x] be a polynomial with roots z₁, …, z_d
    46→with corresponding arguments θ₁, …, θ_d ∈ [0, 2π). Is it true that for all
    47→intervals [α, β] ⊆ [0, 2π),
    48→
    49→  |#{θ_i ∈ [α, β]} − (β − α)/(2π) · d| ≤ C · √(n · log M)
    50→
    51→where C is an absolute constant, n is the number of non-zero coefficients
    52→of f, and M = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / √(|a₀| · |a_d|)?
    53→
    54→Erdős and Turán proved such an upper bound with n replaced by d (the degree).
    55→-/
    56→theorem erdos_problem_990 :
    57→    ∃ C : ℝ, C > 0 ∧
    58→    ∀ (f : Polynomial ℂ),
    59→      f.natDegree ≥ 1 →
    60→      f.coeff 0 ≠ 0 →
    61→      ∀ (α β : ℝ), 0 ≤ α → α ≤ β → β ≤ 2 * Real.pi →
    62→        |(rootArgCount f α β : ℝ) - (β - α) / (2 * Real.pi) * ↑f.natDegree| ≤
    63→          C * Real.sqrt (↑f.support.card * Real.log (erdosTuranMeasure f)) :=
    64→  sorry
    65→
    66→end
    67→

file.content:
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Sqrt
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Basic
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Complex.Arg
import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Roots
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic

open Polynomial Complex Real Finset BigOperators

noncomputable section

/-!
# Erdős Problem #990

Let f = a₀ + ⋯ + a_d xᵈ ∈ ℂ[x] be a polynomial. Is it true that, if f has
roots z₁, …, z_d with corresponding arguments θ₁, …, θ_d ∈ [0, 2π), then
for all intervals I ⊆ [0, 2π)

  |#{θ_i ∈ I} − |I|/(2π) · d| ≪ (n · log M)^{1/2}

where n is the number of non-zero coefficients of f and
M = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / (|a₀| · |a_d|)^{1/2}.

Erdős and Turán [ErTu50] proved such an upper bound with n replaced by d.
-/

/-- The argument of a complex number normalized to [0, 2π).
    Returns 0 for z = 0. -/
noncomputable def Complex.arg2pi (z : ℂ) : ℝ :=
  if Complex.arg z < 0 then Complex.arg z + 2 * Real.pi else Complex.arg z

/-- The number of roots (counted with multiplicity) of a polynomial whose
    argument lies in the interval [α, β]. -/
noncomputable def rootArgCount (f : Polynomial ℂ) (α β : ℝ) : ℕ :=
  (f.roots.map Complex.arg2pi).countP (fun θ => decide (α ≤ θ ∧ θ ≤ β))

/-- The Erdős–Turán measure M(f) = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / √(|a₀| · |a_d|). -/
noncomputable def erdosTuranMeasure (f : Polynomial ℂ) : ℝ :=
  (∑ i ∈ Finset.range (f.natDegree + 1), ‖f.coeff i‖) /
    Real.sqrt (‖f.coeff 0‖ * ‖f.leadingCoeff‖)

/--
Erdős Problem #990 [Er64b]:

Let f = a₀ + ⋯ + a_d xᵈ ∈ ℂ[x] be a polynomial with roots z₁, …, z_d
with corresponding arguments θ₁, …, θ_d ∈ [0, 2π). Is it true that for all
intervals [α, β] ⊆ [0, 2π),

  |#{θ_i ∈ [α, β]} − (β − α)/(2π) · d| ≤ C · √(n · log M)

where C is an absolute constant, n is the number of non-zero coefficients
of f, and M = (|a₀| + ⋯ + |a_d|) / √(|a₀| · |a_d|)?

Erdős and Turán proved such an upper bound with n replaced by d (the degree).
-/
theorem erdos_problem_990 :
    ∃ C : ℝ, C > 0 ∧
    ∀ (f : Polynomial ℂ),
      f.natDegree ≥ 1 →
      f.coeff 0 ≠ 0 →
      ∀ (α β : ℝ), 0 ≤ α → α ≤ β → β ≤ 2 * Real.pi →
        |(rootArgCount f α β : ℝ) - (β - α) / (2 * Real.pi) * ↑f.natDegree| ≤
          C * Real.sqrt (↑f.support.card * Real.log (erdosTuranMeasure f)) :=
  sorry

end

content.text: Now I have all the context. Let me write the formalization.

input.content:
import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic

noncomputable section

open Classical Finset BigOperators

/-!
# Erdős Problem #991

Suppose A = {w₁, …, wₙ} ⊂ S² maximises ∏_{i<j} |wᵢ - wⱼ| over all
possible sets of size n (such sets are called Fekete points).

Is it true that
  max_C | |A ∩ C| - α_C · n | = o(n),
where the maximum is taken over all spherical caps C and α_C is the area
of C (normalised so that the entire sphere has area 1)?

This was proved. Brauchart [Br08] showed O(n^{3/4}) and Marzo–Mas [MaMa21]
improved this to O(n^{2/3}).
-/

/-- The product of pairwise distances of a finite set of points. -/
noncomputable def pairwiseDistProd (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))) : ℝ :=
  ∏ p ∈ P.offDiag, ‖p.1 - p.2‖

/-- A finite set of points on S² maximises the pairwise distance product
    among all sets of the same cardinality on S². -/
def IsMaxPairwiseDist (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))) : Prop :=
  (∀ p ∈ P, ‖p‖ = 1) ∧
  ∀ (Q : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
    (∀ q ∈ Q, ‖q‖ = 1) → Q.card = P.card →
    pairwiseDistProd Q ≤ pairwiseDistProd P

/--
Erdős Problem #991 [Er64b]:

If A = {w₁, …, wₙ} ⊂ S² are Fekete points (maximising the product of
pairwise distances), then the spherical cap discrepancy of A is o(n):
for every ε > 0, if n is large enough and P is any set of n Fekete points,
then for every spherical cap C(v,t) = {x ∈ S² : ⟨x,v⟩ ≥ t},
  ||P ∩ C(v,t)| − ((1−t)/2) · n| ≤ ε · n.

Here (1−t)/2 is the normalised surface area of the cap C(v,t) on S².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_991 :
    ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 →
    ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
      IsMaxPairwiseDist P →
      P.card ≥ N₀ →
      ∀ (v : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3)) (t : ℝ),
        ‖v‖ = 1 → -1 ≤ t → t ≤ 1 →
        |((P.filter (fun x => @inner ℝ _ _ x v ≥ t)).card : ℝ) -
          (1 - t) / 2 * (P.card : ℝ)| ≤ ε * (P.card : ℝ) :=
  sorry

end

import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Group.Finset.Basic

noncomputable section

open Classical Finset BigOperators

/-!
# Erdős Problem #991

Suppose A = {w₁, …, wₙ} ⊂ S² maximises ∏_{i<j} |wᵢ - wⱼ| over all
possible sets of size n (such sets are called Fekete points).

Is it true that
  max_C | |A ∩ C| - α_C · n | = o(n),
where the maximum is taken over all spherical caps C and α_C is the area
of C (normalised so that the entire sphere has area 1)?

This was proved. Brauchart [Br08] showed O(n^{3/4}) and Marzo–Mas [MaMa21]
improved this to O(n^{2/3}).
-/

/-- The product of pairwise distances of a finite set of points. -/
noncomputable def pairwiseDistProd (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))) : ℝ :=
  ∏ p ∈ P.offDiag, ‖p.1 - p.2‖

/-- A finite set of points on S² maximises the pairwise distance product
    among all sets of the same cardinality on S². -/
def IsMaxPairwiseDist (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))) : Prop :=
  (∀ p ∈ P, ‖p‖ = 1) ∧
  ∀ (Q : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
    (∀ q ∈ Q, ‖q‖ = 1) → Q.card = P.card →
    pairwiseDistProd Q ≤ pairwiseDistProd P

/--
Erdős Problem #991 [Er64b]:

If A = {w₁, …, wₙ} ⊂ S² are Fekete points (maximising the product of
pairwise distances), then the spherical cap discrepancy of A is o(n):
for every ε > 0, if n is large enough and P is any set of n Fekete points,
then for every spherical cap C(v,t) = {x ∈ S² : ⟨x,v⟩ ≥ t},
  ||P ∩ C(v,t)| − ((1−t)/2) · n| ≤ ε · n.

Here (1−t)/2 is the normalised surface area of the cap C(v,t) on S².
-/
theorem erdos_problem_991 :
    ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 →
    ∃ N₀ : ℕ, ∀ (P : Finset (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))),
      IsMaxPairwiseDist P →
      P.card ≥ N₀ →
      ∀ (v : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3)) (t : ℝ),
        ‖v‖ = 1 → -1 ≤ t → t ≤ 1 →
        |((P.filter (fun x => @inner ℝ _ _ x v ≥ t)).card : ℝ) -
          (1 - t) / 2 * (P.card : ℝ)| ≤ ε * (P.card : ℝ) :=
  sorry

end

content.text:
Build succeeded. The only warning is the expected `sorry` for the unproved conjecture.

Here's a summary of the formalization in `conjectures/991.lean`:

**Erdős Problem #991**: If A = {w₁, …, wₙ} ⊂ S² are *Fekete points* (maximizing ∏_{i<j} |wᵢ - wⱼ|), then the spherical cap discrepancy is o(n).

The formalization defines:
- **`pairwiseDistProd`** — the product of ‖pᵢ - pⱼ‖ over all ordered pairs in the finset
- **`IsMaxPairwiseDist`** — predicate that a finset of unit sphere points maximizes this product among all same-size subsets of S²
- **`erdos_problem_991`** — the theorem statement: ∀ ε > 0, ∃ N₀ such that for any Fekete set P with |P| ≥ N₀ and any spherical cap C(v,t), the discrepancy ||P ∩ C| - ((1-t)/2)·|P|| ≤ ε·|P|

The formalization follows the same conventions as the related problem 988, using `EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3)` for S² and inner products to define spherical caps.
